```ruby
def test(b)
  b.map { |letter| "I like the letter: #{letter}" }
end

a = ['a', 'b', 'c']
p test(a)
p a
```

```ruby

def test(b)
  b.map! {|letter| "I like the letter: #{letter}" }
end

a = ['a', 'b', 'c']
p test(a)
p a
```

```ruby
def change_name(name)
  name = 'bob'
end

name = 'jim'
p change_name(name)
puts name 
```

```ruby
def add_name(arr, name)
  arr = arr + [name]
end

names = ['bob', 'kim']
p add_name(names, 'jim')
puts names.inspect 
```
```ruby
def add_name(arr, name)
  arr = arr << name
end

names = ['bob', 'kim']
p add_name(names, 'jim')
puts names.inspect
```

```ruby
def tricky_method(a_string_param, an_array_param)
  a_string_param += "rutabaga"
  an_array_param << "rutabaga"
end

my_string = "pumpkins"
my_array = ["pumpkins"]
tricky_method(my_string, my_array)

puts "My string looks like this now: #{my_string}"
puts "My array looks like this now: #{my_array}"
```
```ruby
greetings = { a: 'hi' }
informal_greeting = greetings[:a]
informal_greeting << ' there'

puts informal_greeting  
puts greetings
```
```ruby
greetings = { a: 'hi' }
informal_greeting = {}

greetings.each { |key, value| informal_greeting[key] = value }
informal_greeting[:a] += ' there'

puts informal_greeting
puts greetings
```
on line one we are initaliazing a lcal variable `greeting` and setting assiging the hash object with value {a: `hi`} to it

On `line X` the variable `a` is initialized and the hash object with value `X` is assigned to it.

```ruby
def count_sheep
  5.times do |sheep|
    puts sheep
    if sheep >= 2
      return
    end
  end
end

p count_sheep
```
```ruby
return_value =  [1, 2, 3].select do |num|
                  num + 1
                end
p return_value
```
```ruby
return_value =  [1, 2, 3].map do |num|
                  num.odd?
                end
p return_value
```
```ruby
return_value =  [1, 2, 3].each_with_object([]) do |num, array|
                  array << num if num.odd?
                  puts array.inspect
                end
p return_value
```


```ruby
def real_palindrome?(string)
  string.downcase.delete!('^A-Za-z')
  string
end

p real_palindrome?("Madam, I'm Adam")
```

```ruby
def test(b)
  b.map { |letter| "I like the letter: #{letter}" }
end

a = ['a', 'b', 'c']
p test(a)
p a
```


on `line 1-3` the method `test` is defined that takes 1 parameter `b`.

On `line 5` the local variable `a` is initialized and the array object with value `['a', 'b', 'c']` is assigned to it.

on `line 6` the method `test` is called with the local variable `a` passed to it as an argument. The return value of this method call is then passed to the method `p`. `p`calls the method `inspect`, which returns a string object containing a human-readable representation of the object, this string is then displayed.

On `line 1` the variable ,`b`, local to the method defintion test is set to point to the same array object which is being referenced by the local variable `a`, with value `['a', 'b', 'c']`.
